conversation.content: Did you know octopuses have three hearts?
Wait, seriously? Three hearts? That's absolutely wild. I knew they had blue blood because of the copper, but three hearts is something else entirely.
Yeah, two pump blood to the gills, one to the body.
That's incredible. And here I thought having eight arms was their most impressive feature. Do all three hearts beat at the same time or do they alternate somehow?
They all work together, but the main heart stops when they swim.
Hold on, it stops? The main heart just stops beating while they're swimming? That seems counterintuitive since you'd need more oxygen during physical activity.
That's why they prefer crawling to swimming.
[trailing off] Oh my god, that makes so much sense now... I always wondered why octopuses seemed to crawl along the ocean floor instead of swimming everywhere.
They also have nine brains.
Nine?! Okay, now you're just messing with me. Three hearts was already pushing it, but nine brains? How does that even work anatomically?
One central brain and one mini-brain in each arm.
So each arm can basically think for itself? That's absolutely mind-blowing. No wonder they can open jars and solve puzzles so easily.
The arms can react even after being severed.
[speaking fast] That's genuinely disturbing but fascinating at the same time like some kind of horror movie creature but it's real and living in our oceans right now.
They also have no bones at all.
[pause] Right, of course they don't. They can squeeze through any opening larger than their beak. I've seen videos of them escaping through drains on boats.
Their beak is the only hard part of their body.
A parrot-like beak on a boneless creature with three hearts and nine brains. Evolution really went wild with octopuses. They're basically aliens living on Earth.
Some species can also change their skin texture.
Not just color but texture too? These creatures are biological shapeshifters. Everything about them sounds like science fiction but it's completely real.
